column5: Idk. I started having PTSD symptoms as early as 5-6 so I don‚Äôt really have a concept of what my life looks like without trauma, so for one of the things that has been so hard is never knowing the full potential of who I could have been.  It‚Äôs something I grieve periodically because any time someone says ‚Äúbut it made you such a ‚Äî‚Äî person!‚Äù /insert positive adjective here/ I think- but i could have been that without the trauma. Why should I have had to be hurt so badly to be ‚Äúa good person?‚Äù I think in some ways the devastation I and others feel when our trauma happens so early is really different to how it feels when it happens after you firmly develop who you are as a person, like an adult. I don‚Äôt have a firm sense of life without trauma. But as someone who did, that aspect must be incredibly difficult for you. It‚Äôs more than fair to be frustrated and upset about that loss.

> So why should she make any effort at all? üòí

I‚Äôm not saying she should. I wouldn‚Äôt put in any effort because borderline gonna borderline. I‚Äôm saying the extent of her involvement if she really feels like she wants to should basically be ‚Äúgoogle it yourself.‚Äù Which is about the same level of effort as saying oh, idk. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è‚Äù

> That's because Mom isn't actually going to commit to anything, or finish what she starts.  Easier to be a victim/martyr that way. üòí

Truer words have never been said! My mother decided she wanted to make career swaps at least half a dozen times, try going back to school (never committed) , be a peer counselor (got certificate, never did it), try to do online classes to become a forensic psychologist (failed out because she stopped doing classes) etc. Tbh I‚Äôd just tell her you‚Äôre too busy to help since she‚Äôll blame you if it doesn‚Äôt work out anyways. At most I‚Äôd just say there‚Äôs lots of resources on the internet and leave it at that.

That one was too hard for me in the first episode  because she was really borderline behavior wise from the jump, to the tune of being strikingly like my mother (including an impulsive cross country plane trip without saying anything! Incredible!) I tried to give it an honest shot by doing a couple more episodes but it was just way too much.
Your DHEA and prolactin look a little high. I‚Äôd definitely follow up on those. Adrenal fatigue can cause some of the symptoms you‚Äôre describing.

There‚Äôs a lot of shows I can‚Äôt handle because of the way the people handle themselves. It‚Äôs really distressing so I just stick to rewatching shows I know are safe. I don‚Äôt watch much reality tv, but god do people looooooooooooooooooove Crazy Ex Girlfriend! And literally the first episode she flagged basically all the criteria, but my future SIL was laughing like omg isn‚Äôt this great? And like... consider what that would be like if they were your parent? And the dawning comprehension was a delightful mix of intense discomfort and ‚Äúoh shit did I mess up.‚Äù
Looks casually more like a testosterone problem than a hypothyroid problem. You should also get checked for anemia though and Vitamin D deficiency.
Can you post the ranges for your blood work? Labs use different range norms so it‚Äôs important to see them to be sure.

I think when you‚Äôre deep in the shame and guilt part of PTSD, it‚Äôs hard to have people talking about it openly because you worry it‚Äôll kind of expose you too, you know?  My trauma happened in early childhood and for a long time I couldn‚Äôt speak. I didn‚Äôt have the words, and when the trauma happened screaming for help didn‚Äòt result in being saved. Instead it just made me feel like I hadn‚Äôt tried hard enough to defend myself.  Like I brought it on myself, so I didn‚Äôt deserve to talk about it. 

It took along time to have language and feel safe to talk about what happened. But since I waited almost 23 years to be able to say what happen out loud, in the public square, if you will, I‚Äôm certainly not going back to being quiet. Being quiet and ashamed about having PTSD and trauma only helps the person who repeatedly hurt me. I only have this because someone else decided to hurt me without regard for my life and mental health. I certainly didn‚Äôt choose it for myself, you know? So I get it‚Äôs probably going to be uncomfortable for a while. It‚Äôs still hard for me. But it gets less difficult when you feel stronger.

I‚Äôm so sorry. That was absolutely abuse, and you deserved better parents.  My mother for sure also did the silent treatment but it would be pared with vengeance months down the road for small slights that disproportionately outweighed anything I had possibly done. Favourite examples include: I agreed with my dad on something my mom had definitely said to the two of us, during like. Idk July before my senior year. Later in November, when I had my car at college halfway across the country, she canceled my car insurance without saying anything so I was driving around without car insurance for two months without knowing. Found out when I came home for Christmas. For the next one(s) she told me after I graduated that apparently she hated how I always agreed with my dad (not true, but also when they argued and asked me, it was usually over something she had said to both of us that she was denying she‚Äôd ever said, so she decided she wouldn‚Äôt pay my school tuition on time, and she‚Äôd hide the bills when they came in, claiming they‚Äôd been taken care of. All semesters but 1 when she was in the hospital for like.. 6 weeks and then residential treatment in California for 4 months, I got calls from my college threatening time kick me out during finals for non payment, or rescind housing or take away my class registration. Cue many crying phone calls to parents and bursars office.
My younger sister though- all she did was exist. My maternal grandmother, a staunch catholic, all children gift from god etc, told my mother when she found out she was pregnant with my younger sister, that she had no business having more children because she couldn‚Äôt raise the ones she had (horrible, but true) so my mom basically gave her the ultimate silence treatment , and completely neglected her, even as she became a special needs child due to her inadequacies as a parent. The name of the game for being a parent with BPD is absolutely how can I be the pettiest bitch possible to my sc child in the most disruptive and  life destroying way possible. That explosive anger really is something that should come with an active warning label.

Hello! I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre riding the struggle bus, esp with the current situation. I don‚Äôt know how much help this can be for you, but when I was struggling my junior year while untreated, something that really helped me was to take notes on my laptop while the recording function was going (it‚Äôll flag your bullets as time points in the recording) and then when I got back from class I‚Äôd spend a couple hours each day going back through the lectures I knew I wasn‚Äôt as firm on and rewriting out my notes. Because I had the recording, I could go to a section over and over again until it made sense. Even better is if you have PowerPoint slides for the class ahead of time,  so you can take the notes basically right on top of the power point in real time. PP will also let you record the audio at the same time.  I still use this when I get refreshers on human subjects research certifications. Makes it much easier!

You‚Äôre going to have to study your ass off though. My memory has never been quite what it was. Without post its and my phone I‚Äôd be F-Ed now. However! I was a varsity athlete (spring and fall), made captain my senior year, did 20 hours of lab research junior and senior year, was a lab TA, and graduated with department honors in neural and behavioral sciences.  I have a great job now doing cool research and while I still have bad hypo days, even with a ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù level, it‚Äôs all still doable. Just sometimes harder than others.  You‚Äôll have to think about what your priorities are though, because figuring out what you‚Äôre willing to let go helps significantly with the stress.

My nightmares got worse (and they were already awful!) after I faced my abuser in court because I‚Äôd spent 20 years actively not seeing him and having to be near him made it predictably awful. So I sought out a prescription for  Prazosin, which is an antihypertensive but helps some people with their nightmares. I‚Äôm fortunate that it helps me. It took about 3-4 nights to start feeling effective but I know it works because when I forget to take it, they come streaming back.

Could be a few things. My mom had frequent dissociative episodes (part of the bpd!) and couldn‚Äôt remember what she did, so she‚Äôd cobble together half truths about things and it was pretty clear that‚Äôs what was happening. She just couldn‚Äôt remember because she wasn‚Äôt there mentally. Didn‚Äôt stop her from doing horrible things. The other thing is I read some number of years ago in a study that people with BPD have a really poor sense of object permanence, so case in point my mother tried to tell the court my younger brother was first 12, then 10. My younger brother was 14, almost 15 and pushing 6 feet tall.  She‚Äôd been stuck on talking to the court that he was a little, little kid when he‚Äôs a young man at this point. Meanwhile I only exist once a year to twice a year because she has so much guilt over the fact that I dropped her like hot potatoes and won‚Äôt return her calls or texts, but she‚Äôs been like that most of my adult life. During 4 years of college she remembered to call me maybe 4 times ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è. I exist when I‚Äôm convenient for her or she‚Äôs reminded of me and not a second sooner.

I‚Äôm 28 now, graduated with good grades and departmental honors, celebrated my 10th anniversary with my future wife, etc. You can definitely live your life well.  I tried going off cabergoline for a couple of years for financial reasons (adulthood can be hard!!) and unfortunately it got larger while untreated but my vision is fine, it‚Äôs no where near the optic chiasm, and the cabergoline is really nifty at knocking down the prolactin level pretty fast. Just waiting for my period to come back with a vengeance, lol. I‚Äôm sure the problem would have been noticed way faster had I not been on birth control, since I was symptomatic since at least 17 and just had no clue wtf was going on. Funny how life works!

Hi! I‚Äôm so sorry this is happening to you right before finals and such but I‚Äôve been where you are, and I promise this is not the end of the world. I got diagnosed my junior year of college, and felt much better with treatment. 

I lost my period after being on BCP for about 8ish months for heavy periods and then when I discontinued because of the side effects, I was told to give it a few months and see what happens. Multiple rounds and several months with the college health center later and I suddenly find myself barely getting through my day, absolutely struggling to stay awake and constantly dizzy. To be fair, I also have hypothyroidism (diagnosed same time and often influenced by the prolactinoma) finally, they send me for blood work because I‚Äôve been turfed to the gyno staff since no period automatically means gyno problems üôÑ. They finally shuffled me off to an mri and a referral to an endocrinologist after the lead doc at the health center threw her hands up in the air and said ‚ÄúI know nothing about! But you DEFINITELY don‚Äôt have hypothyroidism!‚Äù (Spoiler- I did. Both are and were possible!)

The first two weeks on cabergoline were a bit of a bear (dizziness, nausea, bloating, difficulty waking morning after taking it), but once it settled in things were way better! It took about 4 months for my period to come back, but lots of other things (the weirdly vague feeling of constant morning sickness, but sans baby) got better really fast. I‚Äôm glad I got diagnosed when I did. Senior year would have been so much harder without treatment.

Less drug tolerance more that your prolactin is fairly high for an adult male. My prolactin was about half yours recently when my doc upped my dosage, and I‚Äôm a 28 year old woman. You will likely need a blood retest, dosage adjust etc until you get wnl, since you‚Äôre on a pretty low dose, per dosing guidelines. When I started treatment, doc put me on .25 mg once a week for two weeks and then had me go up to .25 2x a week so I wouldn‚Äôt get knocked on my ass by the side effects.

Been on cabergoline for 6 of 8 years. When I‚Äôm on a proper dose my libido is significantly better than without, and that‚Äôs generally the case unless my thyroid isn‚Äôt at a good level. I‚Äôm on .5 2x a week though, and the lowest dose I‚Äôve been on is .25 2x a week. Your level might not be optimal yet.
Honestly your levels look pretty good based on the ranges you posted. Are you symptomatic? Your earlier TSH is within range as well- have you been tested for anemia and vitamin deficiencies as well?

It takes a while for the synthroid to really start to work-  6-8 weeks usually. Your hair is already brittle and frail from past damage. I have really long, fine hair that‚Äôs prone to breakage and I have to agree, your shampoo and conditioner matter. You‚Äôre going to need a lot of moisturizing agents for a while and if you use a blow dryer or flat iron at all, stop.  Let your hair air dry as much as possible, don‚Äôt wash every day, and get a hair mask periodically for deep conditioning. It will get better, but much like with your skin now, you have to make more of an effort to keep your hair from being super dry. Good luck and I‚Äôm so sorry. I know it‚Äôs hard and super upsetting in the beginning of things.

Foods like these: soy and cassava, cabbage, broccoli, cauliflower, and other cruciferous vegetables (see [NIH info](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Iodine-HealthProfessional/) for more on the condition) but tbh you have to eat a truly horrendous amount to hinder it. If you‚Äôre eating a balanced diet you should be fine. Don‚Äôt stop your medication without talking to your doctor: it‚Äôs replacing something your body has trouble handling on it‚Äôs own. It‚Äôs medication your body needs to help fulfill your basic metabolic functioning.

I only need more than 6-7 when I‚Äôm incredibly under medicated, but I‚Äôve had persistent sleep disturbance for 22 years (28 now) thanks to childhood trauma. Before I got diagnosed though I needed to sleep 12-14 hours a day.

Mines partially genetic (my mom has it too) and I have a prolactinoma which can throw things out of whack. There‚Äôs a lot of things that can cause it. It also just be that your pituitary is out of whack ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è some medications can interfere with your pituitary and thyroid functioning as well. Generally if you‚Äôre in a developed country with a good, balanced diet Iodine deficiency is unlikely to be your problem unless you are consuming an excessive amount of foods that interfere with uptake.

Diagnosed and started treatment at twenty, on synthroid for 6 years on a variety of doses. Primary symptoms started with cold all the time (in multiple layers, 85 degree room), sudden weight gain with sharp decrease in appetite, horrible fatigue (I‚Äôd be about to fall asleep in class), constipation, low mood and anxiety, sleeping 12ish hours a day, brittle and ridged nails, hair and eyebrows falling out, memory fog. I stopped treatment about 2-1/2 years ago because I suddenly found myself unable to afford bloodwork, doc visits, and meds. Figured if I tapered off I‚Äôd be ok. 

I was able to afford primary care again recently and got the bloodwork done. I‚Äôd noticed it was hard to get out of bed again, my eyebrows and nails were not doing well, had poor attention span and was starting to have memory fog, gained more weight and started having constipation again. My TSH  was at like a 14.2. Personally, I don‚Äôt recommend going off your thyroid treatment. The symptoms either slam back on or creep in until one day you‚Äôre sitting there trying to figure out why everything feels awful and wrong. Your body is lacking the ability to do something, the medication helps on some level. The dose or type of medication might just not be right or you might have another condition.

The reference range for normal often tops at around 4.5. Anything over is indicative of under functioning thyroid. However, individual people have different responses to levels overtime. In feb I tested for 14.5 or so, and while symptomatic felt less cruddy than I had about 8 years ago when I was at 4.3. 5 years ago I was on 75 mcgs of levo and had a tsh of 11 and felt like I had a chronic low grade flu. 4.84 is not so ‚Äúbad,‚Äù but likely just not optimal for you or anyone! I feel best when I‚Äôm around 1.5 to 2 :) hopefully you start feeling better soon! I freaked out at first. But having labs is knowledge and knowledge is a powerful tool in getting care for these things.

I know how you feel! I got diagnosed at 20 after the more serious symptoms kicked in and had been going on for 8+ months. The primary care person I saw didn‚Äôt think it needed to be bothered with. I got lucky and had a different endocrine issue that required referral out to an endocrinologist, who was willing to see that while my level was ‚Äúin range‚Äù, I was symptomatic and trying me on a low dose wasn‚Äôt going to hurt. Be firm about how it affects your day to day functioning and if you can, sit down and start documenting your symptoms, when they onset, what seems to affect you the worst. Establishing timelines and coming armed with knowledge of your present illness helps you be your own advocate, especially when/if the memory fog comes for you. If you have a partner who is willing to come along and corroborate some of this and help you advocate, all the better.

Two things: Have you been tested for anemia as well? Anemia plus B12 deficiency would also explain most symptoms. 

The other is that your TSH range is larger than any I‚Äôve seen in the last 5 years. For all the testing I‚Äôve gotten, usually the upper limit of ‚Äúnormal‚Äù is 4.5 mIU/L. Additionally if your blood draw was earlier in the day the level is likely to be lower than at the end of the day.  However, I am always symptomatic at 3-4, so if anemia isn‚Äôt an issue, chances are good that you have some form of Hypo.

I have always been medicated at 4.5. The American association of clinical endocrinologists has said since at least 2012 that thyroids between 3-5 should be considered suspicious at the least and have advocated for the upper limit to be lowered to 3 since the average skews closer to 1.5. Your TSH is high enough to be symptomatic, and while that wasn‚Äôt high enough for a Gp (who poopooed there being anything wrong besides needing more exercise when I was a Div III year round athlete), it was high enough for the endocrinologist she referred me to. https://journals.aace.com/doi/pdf/10.4158/EP12280.GL

Do you have your labs? Some GPs aren‚Äôt aware that the guidelines for what‚Äôs considered high have changed drastically in the last few years. You are highly symptomatic and if you quality for the diagnosis now, you need the medication now. Unfortunately a lot of us have found you need to be firm in bring your own advocate. Good luck.

Essentially you don‚Äôt want to be taking in calories when you take it because it forces your system to compete with the food for clean absorption. Your metabolism is already slow (that‚Äôs why you‚Äôre taking this) so if you think about how your body already has issues absorbing nutrients in a timely fashion, you‚Äôre making it that much harder for the levo/thyroid replacement to get into your bloodstream by diluting in your food. The American thyroid association has a blurb on it, and the cited a study that showed a pretty decent difference. https://www.thyroid.org/patient-thyroid-information/ct-for-patients/vol-6-issue-11/vol-6-issue-11-p-4/. You might not know if you‚Äôre that sensitive or not, but days where I don‚Äôt wait long enough because I‚Äôm being absent minded, I do feel a difference if I drink my tea (honey and cream) too soon.

I did from about 17-19. Then I went on bc to help the painful, 2x a month, week long, heavy periods. I hated how I felt and decided to go off it because it made me feel cruddy physically and didn‚Äôt help the pain really. Suddenly I had zero period and got told it wasn‚Äôt an issue when it was 4 months post stopping. I didn‚Äôt get my period for over a full year after stopping. With the cabergoline I get it 1x a month, still lasts a week, but only the first 3 days are heavy now.

I‚Äôm so sorry. This happened to me and it was really frustrating as a college student to have everything blamed on depression when it was pretty clear that I had physical symptoms beyond fatigue. Unfortunately, hypo is a known mimic condition for depression, _which is why a doctor is supposed to test your thyroid before starting antidepressants_, but I digress. I‚Äôm sorry you lost all those years, but here‚Äôs to the road to getting your life back.

I didn‚Äôt get a peripheral vision test until about 4ish years after I got diagnosed and started having visual acuity loss. Other than that, I did a hormone panel (important!! Other things may very well be affected by a tumor), MRI, and had a follow up panel a few months later after I had an in office visit and physical exam by an endo.

My condition came on while dating my long term partner. They noticed a vague difference in how my skin around that area tasted before I started treatment but otherwise I haven‚Äôt had significant enough discharge anytime I‚Äôve been without medication for some reason that it‚Äôs that noticeable. I‚Äôd say that you could get away without saying something for a while, especially if you aren‚Äôt sexually active with the person yet. In the mean time I‚Äôd say go ask a doctor for something to help deal with the issue/get tested. Then you might not even have to deal with having a conversation about it in the present tense.

Hey- cool news dude- I‚Äôm a neuroscientist. I read everything I could about this before taking my first dose. You‚Äôre assuming this is a community of sheep who can‚Äôt be bothered to read up about their own condition, and that‚Äôs really not true.  Of course her body feels like it needs it. It‚Äôs potent. We all know it comes with weighty side effects, but it‚Äôs often better than its predecessor, and those of us who don‚Äôt qualify for surgery have few options. 

She was taking a serious medication to treat a medical condition that has incredibly few options beyond radiation or surgery.  Her body is crying out for it because it was helping regulate her system, and these conditions often cause other pituitary illnesses that won‚Äôt resolve unless you treat the prolactinoma. If she‚Äôs coming off it too fast it will absolutely feel like withdrawal. You‚Äôre supposed to slowly taper off the medication.  You may have come here for support, but here‚Äôs the thing: if you were being respectful and not just trying to scare people about their treatment options, you‚Äôd have noted that the community header says it‚Äôs for people with prolactinomas to talk about their treatment, symptoms and experiences. It‚Äôs not your illness, so you don‚Äôt have those experiences.

I‚Äôve been on and off this medication for 8 years. Never once have any of these things been an issue for me. Before the cabergoline I completely lost my sex drive. Cabergoline gave me my life back. I‚Äôve lurked on this forum for several years and no one else has reported anything of this severity. _generally you don‚Äôt see these issues unless you‚Äôre on dosages high enough for treating Parkinson‚Äôs_. Your wife may have just gotten the rough end of the stick, but don‚Äôt you dare come here trying to frighten people who come here for support. YOU need therapy to deal with your marriage, not to come to a support board for people with a medical condition you don‚Äôt understand.

Been basically NC for almost 4 years. Best decision I ever made. I‚Äôm happier, healing, get paid more, stand up for myself. And don‚Äôt wake up to birthday messages telling me I‚Äôm a huge bitch for not returning her calls. It‚Äôs hard at first but it gets easier and now I delightedly tell people my mother isn‚Äôt in my life full stop because of choices she made. It‚Äôs her shame, not mine.

Of course! I wish I could claim credit for it, but I can‚Äôt. I merely pass it on to those who seem like they need it.

LOL. Pleaseeeeee. I‚Äôm sure plenty of people her age _have also dropped acid_.  She wants to be waited on hand and foot after throwing her hands up and deciding that nothing but living with you will do (cue nightmare screams).

Yeah, once I realized that she was subconsciously of the opinion ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs mine is mine and what‚Äôs yours in mine‚Äù  it helped a lot in terms of organizing myself. I think the absolute worst though was when she decided to self publish a book of poetry and she was going to just use artwork from my sketch books without asking, _including a piece I drew symbolizing how I felt living in the same house as her_. The lack of awareness was impressive.
Lmao yeah- loved the kids right up until they were inconvenient or decided to disagree with her üôÑ

You know it is always shocking to me how much other people were willing to overlook or not comment on my mother‚Äôs behavior, but then later in life tell me they knew something was up. It made me mad and frustrated at first because holy shit I was so depressed! Why didn‚Äôt you help me??? As I moved towards lower and lower levels of contact, people would ask me how my mom was and it was always so very awkward explaining over and over that we weren‚Äôt talking and why. And I think people just don‚Äôt societally want to talk about abusive mothers. Obviously people can‚Äôt understand being estranged from family in general, but g-d forbid you cut the sacred tether from one‚Äôs mother.   It‚Äôs hard to understand why people didn‚Äôt step in for me, but then I remember how my mother could be anybody a a handful of hours. Never consistently, mind you, but she presented so many fa√ßades to the world that I don‚Äôt know if anyone else but my dad and I could keep up.

Nope! This is completely reasonable! You brought up some great points about the kind of place she needs to live, and if she can‚Äôt be independent without significant family help, a senior community is a great place for her! People her own age, help nearby, etc you were more than logical on this suggestion. You called her bluff and she got pissy. You are allowed to have your own life, and kudos on being firm on the boundary. JADE-ing doesn‚Äôt help, so ultimately this is for the best. When it comes to our pwBPD, it‚Äôs important to keep this in mind: play bitch games, win shit prizes. The only way to really win is not to play. Your cutting the convo off the way you did is just you deciding not to play anymore.  You did a great jobüëçüôå

Woof big mood on the mom taking the clothes when you‚Äôre out and wearing them. I am absolutely convinced that when I needed size 6 pants as a 12 year old, she took me to the petite old ladies section as an excuse to expand her closet, because she never let me get clothes I liked or fit in with my peer group. When I got older and left non seasonal items at home, I‚Äôd come back and find half my summer wardrobe gone. It was so infuriating when we wore the same size. I was always so glad when her weight fluctuated WAY off mine so I could stop crying about her taking my shit. 

She‚Äôd also just rearrange my entire desk and book case while I was gone and it made me so mad because I had EVERYTHING sorted, but she‚Äôd say she had to clean my room even though I left it clean when I‚Äôd go back to school.  It really has a way of making you feel like nothing is safe.

Usual disclaimer: if she‚Äôs threatening, call 911. Unfortunately with pwBPD, the high impulsivity plus fear of abandonment sometimes leads to more dire attempts than others. _unfortunately_ you likely won‚Äôt know which it is until it‚Äôs too late. 

Out of the 6+ attempts during my sophomore year of high school, only one was truly life threatening. Of the 5 or so since I went to college, 1 was life threatening, but likely survivable. The problem is that while often predictable in their behavior patterns, our parents with BPD are more likely to use whatever they can get their hands on, see: impulsive behavior. 

That said: you have to live your life. Any decision she makes is out of your hands and not all your fault. You don‚Äôt need to set yourself on fire to keep her warm, and the financial help you do give her is already more than she should be asking for.  You are your own person with your own ambitions, hopes, and dreams for the future, not an extension of your parent. Trying to predict which attempt might be the serious one will just keep you feeling constantly anxious if you let it.

My mother did this to me a few years back (same method, similar message- seen one you‚Äôve seen then all!) and it made me feel horribly safe too, and I am half a country away. Luckily my partner knew better than to respond and blocked her but it sent my anxiety into overdrive. I‚Äôve essentially blocked her on everything since even a text message or a phone call makes me anxious. My bpd mom is actually why I can‚Äôt answer the phone anymore if I don‚Äôt recognize the caller.   She then got ‚Äúupset‚Äù and decided to fly across the country and just. Be on my doorstep on a weekend I was supposed to be out of town for several days.  I felt so violated that she could do that. 

You‚Äôre not alone that you feel unsafe. The apartment I wound up moving to later has a gated entry, plus a locked door, on top of a multi locked door.  It‚Äôs the only way I feel safe and secure in my home anymore. Obviously barring your ability to move, if your door doesn‚Äôt have secondary locks, having additional locks (like a chain) might be helpful. I wish I had answers for how you feel safe again, but until there is a definitive end I think the worry remains because we know what our parent with bpd is capable of :/ I had moved and not told my parent where (yay! Increased feelings of safety), but unfortunately I sued my abuser in civil proceedings and then she got my address again :/ 

All this is to say so many of us understand how you feel. And it‚Äôs not impossible to get to feeling safe again. It just takes time. I‚Äôm so sorry that this happened though, and I hope the nightmares stop soon.
